description: An article on Thursday about vaccine misinformation prevalent in Black and Latino communities misstated the year that the Tuskegee syphilis study began. It started in 1932, not 1943.

title: Why I Took a Vow of Celibacy
description: Twenty months ago, I took a vow of celibacy that had nothing to do with religion. I had just come out of a two-year relationship that had ended messily, and I felt exhausted at the soul level. Not just by what it had taken to extricate my heart from this particular maelstrom of shattered promises and lingering disappointments, but by the whole thing, the dozens of relationships so much like this one that they seemed to exist in an echo chamber.

title: What Happened When Germanys Far-Right Party Railed Against Lockdowns
description: BERLIN  In November, as Covid-19 cases began to rise, thousands of people gathered in Berlin to protest against restrictions. In among the conspiracy theorists and extremists were several lawmakers from the countrys main opposition party, the far-right, anti-immigration Alternative for Germany.

title: Jimmy Kimmel Reminisces About One Year of Living Contagiously
description: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous nights highlights that lets you sleep  and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Were all stuck at home at the moment, so here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

title: Word of the Day: ilk
Hungary pays big for a Chinese vaccine.
description: Hungary has agreed to pay about $36 a dose for the Covid-19 vaccine made by Sinopharm, a Chinese state-owned company, according to contracts made public by a senior Hungarian official on Thursday. That appears to make the Sinopharm shot among the most expensive in the world.

title: Drawing a Crowd
Trump as Youve Never Seen Him Before
description: There is no shortage of merchandise in China devoted to the former president of the United States, Donald J. Trump. There are commemorative coins, toilet brushes and cat toys; countless figurines, including updated versions of Mount Rushmore, plus all those flags, bumper stickers and hats from campaigns past and future. (Does anyone still believe all that Make America Great Again stuff was really made in America?)

title: Lesson of the Day: How Some States Are Moving to Restrict Transgender Women in Sports
description: Featured Article: How Some States Are Moving to Restrict Transgender Women in Sports by Gillian R. Brassil

title: Harpo Marx, South Carolinas Voting History and Other Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Weekly Health Quiz: Runner's High, Vaccine Side Effects and Life After Vaccination
description: Test your knowledge of this weeks health news.

title: New in Paperback: Dirt and The Night Watchman
description: THE YELLOW BIRD SINGS, by Jennifer Rosner. (Flatiron, 304 pp., $16.99.) A 5-year-old music prodigy who must be quiet while hiding with her mother in a hayloft in World War II Poland, after the rest of their family has been murdered, takes comfort in the trill of a bird she grasps in her hands. Rosners novel, which our reviewer, Mary Beth Keane, called exquisite and heartrending, was a 2020 National Jewish Book Award finalist.

title: When the Pilgrims Met the Native Americans
description: TERROR TO THE WICKED

title: The New York Times News Quiz, March 12, 2021
description: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.

title: Should High School-Age Basketball Players Be Able to Get Paid?
description: Starting on March 18, some of the best college athletes in the world will be competing in the N.C.A.A. basketball tournament. Will you be watching and cheering it this year?

title: When Hell Is Coming to Terms With Other People, and Yourself
description: SEX WITH STRANGERSStoriesBy Michael Lowenthal

title: How Americas Covid-19 Nightmare Ends
description: On Jan. 28, I published a column that began like this: I hope, in the end, that this article reads as alarmism. I hope that a year from now its a piece people point to as an overreaction.

title: Vaccines Are Here. So Is Reckless Behavior.
description: One year ago this week, we began to go to war with our hands. We were told to keep them away from our faces  keep them from people and banisters and elevator buttons and other destinations toward which they were naturally inclined. When they failed to obey, they were scrubbed and sanitized to the bone.

title: Taylor Swift Is Singing Us Back to Nature
description: I had just started to scrub the sheet pan when I saw the glare from across the sink.

title: Nobody Wants to Be There, Dude: How a Jurors Podcast Led to an Appeal
description: Like many New Yorkers, Jake Letizia, a freelance video editor and standup comedian, holds strong opinions and loves to share them. But when he was selected for jury duty in Manhattan more than a year ago, he and his fellow jurors received strict instructions from the judge not to talk about the case with anyone.

title: Which Families Will Receive the Most Money From the Stimulus Bill?
description: The Covid-19 relief legislation signed by President Biden on Thursday includes a larger increase in direct aid to families than in any other pandemic relief bills passed so far  an average of $6,660 for households with children, according to an analysis by the nonpartisan Tax Policy Center.

title: The Way to His Heart Was Through His Stomachache
description: Three weeks after Jennifer Camilla Berger and Jesse Prestwood-Taylor began dating in summer 2014 they came down with a bout of food poisoning together. (They blame an avocado).

title: For Gig Workers and Business Owners, Taxes Are Even Trickier Now
description: Tax time is always complicated for freelancers and business owners, but this year, its especially swampy.

title: A Break for Working Families
description: Working families who rely on a federal tax credit to help pay the bills are getting a break this tax season: They can qualify for the credit based on whichever years income  2019 or 2020  puts the most cash in their pocket.

title: Hearing My Dead Wifes Voice in the Pandemics Silence
description: My wife died six months before the pandemic struck. Already alone, I was now quarantined with my grief in a house the virus had narrowed from confining to claustrophobic. If the disease didnt choke me, I worried that loneliness would. My children call every day and I speak by phone with a few close friends, but loneliness breeds in a silent house.

title: Covid Vaccines Arent Enough. We Need More Tests.
description: Theres reason for optimism on the coronavirus pandemic: The number of new Covid-19 cases is dropping, and 98.2 million doses of coronavirus vaccines have been administered in the United States. But a decline in the number of coronavirus tests being conducted threatens this progress, because those tests are vital to tracing the path and velocity of Covid-19.

title: Need Health Insurance? A Guide to New Options Under the Stimulus.
description: The stimulus package signed by President Biden on Thursday provides new options for Americans who need health insurance  and new resources to help lower costs for those who are already insured.

title: A Love Letter to My Accountant
description: I stopped doing my own taxes the year after I sold my first novel. I had, I still have, a great fear of the Internal Revenue Service as an artist. I know my history  back taxes is how they get you, especially if youre a Black artist, especially, especially, if you are publicly critical of the project known as the United States.  I was terrified of making what felt like even a modicum of gains only to wake up one day with it all gone. It is, perhaps, telling of the lengths of my pessimism that this was my first thought after my agent told me shed found a publishing house for the book Id been working on for six years.

title: It May Be Time to Start Worrying About the Estate Tax
description: Under current rules, the federal estate tax wont ever affect you unless youre quite wealthy. But that could change rapidly, even if you are far from rich.

title: Joe Biden Knew He Was Onto Something Long Before We Did
description: Last year, as he steamrolled his way to victory in the Democratic presidential primaries, Joe Biden told CNN that the pandemic was probably the biggest challenge in modern history, quite frankly.

title: How the Pandemic Has Changed Your Taxes
description: The pandemic year of 2020 was a doozy. Besides affecting the health, jobs, home lives and psyches of millions of Americans, the pandemic may also have consequences for your tax bill.

title: In a Fearful China, Its Dr. Fauci Wins Hearts With Restraint
description: China has imposed some of the toughest lockdowns in the world to stop Covid-19. One city sealed apartment doors, leaving residents with dwindling food and medicine. One village tied a local to a tree after he left home to buy cigarettes. Beijing forced people to leave their pets behind when they went into quarantine.

title: Finding Common Ground and Love in Harlem
description: When telling the story of their relationship, April Hunt and June Berry sometimes leave out a detail the listener is bound to find significant. We forgot to tell you that a portrait of us was hanging in the National Gallery in Washington, Ms. Hunt said the day before her Feb. 12 wedding to Ms. Berry.

title: The Tax Headaches of Working Remotely
description: Last year, Ariele Doolittle, a tax lawyer, got a call from a client who lived and worked in New York but was considering working remotely from California temporarily after his offices were shuttered in the pandemic.

title: How a Rockaways Pizza Chef Spends Her Sundays
description: In 2012, after Hurricane Sandy devastated much of the Rockaways in Queens, Nicole Russell, a longtime resident of Arverne by the Sea, a community there, began making pizzas out of her home. She did this in part to please her sister, Joan, a pizza lover who had recently learned she had cancer.

title: A Buyout Fund C.E.O. Got in Tax Evasion Trouble. Heres Why Investors Shrugged.
description: Last fall, Robert F. Smith, the billionaire founder of Vista Equity Partners, a private equity firm, paid $139 million to federal authorities to settle one of the biggest tax evasion cases in American history.

title: How a British Gardening Show Got People Through the Pandemic
description: The television show Gardeners World is an institution in Britain, where it has aired for coming up on 54 seasons, having premiered way back in 1968. It broadcasts on Friday nights, welcomed by viewers as a gentle usher into the weekend.

title: Faulty Software Snarls Vaccine Sign-Ups
description: When coronavirus vaccines first became available, state health officials in Virginia turned to software recommended by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention to schedule appointments. But people complained that the software, called VAMS, was too confusing for older adults to use.

title: In Nevada, Unemployed Workers Wait for Aid That Will Still Not Be Enough
description: LAS VEGAS  Bobby Hernandez plans to spend his stimulus check on medication to manage his diabetes. Wilma Estrella will use hers to pay the electricity bill. Lizbeth Ramos intends to catch up on the rent, though the money will not be enough to cover all that she owes.

title: I Just Wanted To Disappear: Women Saw Themselves in Meghans Pregnancy Struggle
description: Oprah Winfreys interview with Meghan and Harry has clearly become a spark for international discussions about racism and the state of Britains royal family. And it has brought new attention to another issue as well.

title: Get Outside and Safely Visit a National Park
description: Expansive vistas, serene lakes, abundant wildlife and good old fresh air  whats not to love about national parks? So many Americans have taken refuge in parks during the pandemic that 15 of them set recreation visitation records in 2020. All of the parks have adjusted their operations as a result of Covid-19, and with social-distancing protocols still in place almost a year later, there could be competition for campsites, ferry rides, programs and, in some cases, day passes at the most popular parks.

title: In Nigeria, Feminist Was a Common Insult. Then Came the Feminist Coalition.
description: LAGOS, Nigeria  During the biggest demonstrations in Nigerias recent history, 13 women came together to support their fellow citizens risking their lives to march against police brutality.

title: The Secret Stunt Doubles of the Art World
description: When film and TV crews need to set up cameras, or adjust lighting and sound equipment, actors stand-ins  people of a similar size and shape  are often called in to patiently take their place. And when a script calls for a character to do something dangerous, the star usually steps aside while a stunt double takes the punch.

title: Chinas answer to Dr. Fauci wins hearts with candor and respect.
description: China imposed some of the worlds toughest lockdowns to stop the coronavirus. One city sealed apartment doors, leaving residents with dwindling food and medicine. One village tied a local man to a tree after he left home to buy cigarettes.

title: Democrats Split From Cuomo as Impeachment Inquiry Looms
description: [Want to get New York Today by email? Heres the sign-up.]

title: Odessa, Part 2: Friday Night Lights
description: New episodes of Odessa will be released as they become available here and wherever you get your podcasts.

title: Odessa, Part 2: Friday Night Lights
description: New episodes of Odessa will be released as they become available here and wherever you get your podcasts.

title: ISIS Forced Them Into Sexual Slavery. Finally, Theyve Reunited With Their Children.
description: FAYSH KHABUR BORDER CROSSING, Iraq  The nine young mothers rushed into the spartan offices of a Syrian border post, looking for the sons and daughters taken from them two years ago, children they thought they would never see again.

title: The Image and the Intrigue: Covering the Royal Family
description: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.

title: Hope as a Public Health Tool
description: The early coronavirus mistakes were mostly mistakes of excessive optimism. Many scientists, including Dr. Anthony Fauci, did not immediately grasp the threat. Neither did we in the media. President Donald Trump made the extreme version of this mistake, with a series of false statements minimizing the problem. Some politicians continue to show undue optimism, ending mask mandates and allowing full restaurants.

title: Europe Struggles to Defend Itself Against a Weaponized Dollar
description: BRUSSELS  The new Biden administration is making nice with the European Union, talking of renewed cooperation and suspending retaliatory tariffs stemming from an old dispute between Airbus and Boeing.

title: Yes Day Review: Its a Family Affair
description: Ice cream for breakfast? Silly costumes in public? Parents are required to give the green light to every request on Yes Day, a designated 24-hour period when kids take charge.

title: Australian Minister Settles Defamation Complaint for Lying Cow Remark
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  Australias defense minister on Friday settled a defamation complaint and agreed to pay damages to a former aide whom she called a lying cow after the woman reported being raped in the Parliament building.

title: Own the Room Review: Chasing Their Entrepreneurial Dreams
description: Entrepreneurship is a gamble, so it seems noteworthy that the Global Student Entrepreneur Awards, with a $100,000 prize for the best pitch, takes place in casino-heavy Macau, off the coast of Hong Kong. But the five young subjects of this documentary, Own the Room (streaming on Disney+), are gambling on us as much as we are on them.

title: Spurred by Tragedy to a Life of Female Empowerment
description: THIAROYE-SUR-MER, Senegal  Sometimes when shes alone and looking at the sea, Yayi Bayam Diouf imagines the silhouette of her son passing over the waters offshore.

title: New Adversary Looms for Trump as Vance Exits Manhattan D.A. Race
description: Cyrus R. Vance Jr., the Manhattan district attorney, announced on Friday he would not run for re-election, setting off a wide-open race to lead one of the most important crime-fighting offices in the country and making it highly likely that any potential case against President Donald J. Trump will be left in a newcomers hands.

title: A Midsummer Nights Dream, Sprinkled With High-Tech Fairy Dust
description: A Midsummer Nights Dream may be one of Shakespeares most performed plays  but its latest version from the Royal Shakespeare Company will be unlike any seen before. Titled Dream, the 50-minute streamed production fuses live performance with motion-capture technology, 3-D graphics, and interactive gaming techniques that let the audience remotely guide Puck through a virtual forest.

title: How to Get on the Ballot in a Pandemic
description: We spent the day with Dianne Morales as she worked with volunteers to find people to sign a petition in order to get her name on the primary ballot.

title: Speaking of Britney Spears, What About the Others?: The Week in Narrated Articles
description: Take out your headphones and put down your phone. Now you can listen to New York Times journalism narrated by the reporters who wrote the story, or by world-class narrators.

title: The Falcon and the Winter Soldier Is Marvels Latest Double Act
description: When Anthony Mackie got the call that the executives at Marvel Studios wanted to meet with him shortly after the release of the 2019 superhero blockbuster Avengers: Endgame, he figured he was either getting a new gig or getting fired.

title: Rescuing an Off Off Broadway Theater With a Storied Past
description: When Edith OHara, the mother hen and indefatigable leader of the eclectic 13th Street Repertory Company for nearly half a century, died last fall at age 103, the future became decidedly shaky for one of Off Off Broadways longest-operating stages.

title: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Ashish Jha
description: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like todays episode with Ashish Jha.  Listen wherever you get your podcasts.

title: Americas Cup Tied After Starts Again Prove Decisive
description: With the start once again playing the decisive role, Team New Zealand and Luna Rossa each won a race at the Americas Cup in Auckland, New Zealand.

title: What to Know Now About the Newsom Recall Effort
description: Good morning.

title: Is It Time to Abolish the Monarchy?
description: To the Editor:

title: A Very Hoya Engagement
description: Ashley Singleton and Nathan Arrowsmith took a photograph together within minutes of meeting each other in 2017. The image doesnt mark the moment they fell in love, or even the first time they felt drawn to one another. That all came later.

title: When They Knew, They Knew. And Nothing Else Mattered.
description: On Cinco de Mayo in 2019, Candace Brisco went out with a group of friends. Later that night, she couldnt fall asleep. The question Do you like a girl? wouldnt leave her mind.

title: Romance Blossomed. A Home Garden Bloomed.
description: In the years leading up to 2019, Lane Harris watched the landscape around her home in Ithaca, N.Y., become overgrown. Weeds crept up the raised bed in the backyard. Woody shrubs bombarded the lilac bush. The fig tree was ailing.

title: Teamwork and Chemistry Leads to Marriage
description: During the course of their four-year relationship, Dr. Alexis Catherine Gomez and Dr. Taylor Francis Baumann have been new friends and best friends and then boyfriend and girlfriend.

title: Desperate for a Trip? Here Are the Questions to Ask Before You Go.
description: Like millions of people who have been able to work from home this past year, Gigi Gomez was desperate for a change of scenery.

title: Some Changes That May Affect Next Years Tax Return
description: This past year may have been one of the most complicated tax seasons ever, but there are also recent updates that may affect your taxes when you file your return next year.

title: A Mansion Sale Built on the Myth of a Notorious Cow
description: Daisy the cow almost certainly did not start the Great Chicago Fire.

title: A Year of Risk, Fear and Loss for Families in Medicine
description: Gabrielle Dawn Luna sees her father in every patient she treats.

title: British Police Officer Charged With Murder in Killing of Sarah Everard
description: LONDON  A  police officer was charged late Friday with kidnapping and murdering Sarah Everard, a marketing executive who went missing in South London last week and whose disappearance had touched off a national outcry over violence against women.

title: Colorado Braces for a Major Snowstorm This Weekend
description: A significant late-season winter storm is expected to blanket parts of Colorado with up to four feet of snow over the weekend, creating hazardous travel conditions and prompting Gov. Jared Polis to activate the Colorado National Guard.

title: With a Rose Garden celebration, Biden takes a victory lap.
description: One day after President Biden gave a televised address promising that his $1.9 trillion American Rescue Plan would help lift up an economy stunned by the coronavirus pandemic, he entered the Rose Garden to a standing ovation from an audience of Democrats.

title: Kansas and Virginia Pull Out of Conference Tournaments Because of Virus
description: Two of college basketballs marquee teams, Kansas and Virginia, withdrew from their conference tournaments on Friday because of coronavirus cases, imperiling their prospects to contend for a national championship in a season defined  and routinely complicated  by the pandemic.

title: Economic Road Rage
description: As stock markets set new highs, Karen Petrou is mad about monetary policy. Ms. Petrou, co-founder and managing partner of Federal Financial Analytics, a Washington-based consultancy, got so angry that she wrote a book about it, Engine of Inequality: The Fed and the Future of Wealth in America. In it, she draws a direct connection between the Federal Reserves decisions and the rich getting richer, with others struggling to get by.

title: What to Cook This Weekend
description: Good morning. J. Kenji Lpez-Alt has been up late lately, experimenting with techniques for making airy, Viennese-style schnitzel. He went deep on pounding, on eggs, on bread crumbs, on fat and, crucially, on vodka and swirling. The recipe (above) that resulted from his labors will deliver a terrifically puffy, shatteringly crisp crust, with a perfectly done, moist interior, whether you use pork or veal.

title: Bidens I Need You: A Welcome Change
description: To the Editor:

title: Cuomo Says He Wont Bow to Cancel Culture and Rejects Calls to Resign
description: Facing a deluge of calls to resign from New Yorks U.S. senators and the majority of its House Democrats, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo made clear on Friday he had no intention of quitting, deriding the mounting pressure from his own party as cancel culture and insisting he would not bow to it.

title: Kill the Office Dress Code
description: The question of what to wear to work shouldnt pose an unanswerable dilemma.

title: Dont Reject the Champions Leagues Changes Out of Hand
description: Say what you like about Andrea Agnelli, but at least he is not afraid of a bad idea. Even by the standards of Agnelli, the Juventus chairman, this has been a fairly spectacular week, a seemingly never-ending stream of free-form thoughts about the future of soccer, each one somehow worse than the last.

title: Getting the Best Out of Thick Asparagus
description: When I was a kid, my father planted asparagus in a sunny corner of our Brooklyn backyard.

title: The U.S. will partner with Japan, India and Australia to expand global vaccine supply.
description: The Biden administration, under intense pressure to donate excess coronavirus vaccines to needy nations, is moving to address the global shortage in another way: by partnering with Japan, India and Australia to finance a dramatic expansion of the vaccine manufacturing capacity.

title: SZA Teases Whats Next, and 11 More New Songs
description: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the weeks most notable new songs and videos. Just want the music? Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes). Like what you hear? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com and sign up for our Louder newsletter, a once-a-week blast of our pop music coverage.

title: Why Older People Managed to Stay Happier Through the Pandemic
description: For all its challenges to mental health, this year of the plague also put psychological science to the test, and in particular one of its most consoling truths: that age and emotional well-being tend to increase together, as a rule, even as mental acuity and physical health taper off.

title: Sacha Baron Cohen Has a Message for Mark Zuckerberg
description: The actor who, as Borat, drew our attention to racism, misogyny and autocratic propaganda calls out the social media companies who profit off these trends.

title: Fred Figa, Who Helped Expose a Drugs Dangers, Is Dead at 65
description: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

title: A Rift Over Art and Activism Ripples Through the Performance World
description: At a conference of performing arts presenters, in January 2020, Jedediah Wheeler, the executive director of Peak Performances at Montclair State University in New Jersey, introduced the choreographer Emily Johnson. Wheeler called himself the luckiest person in the room to be commissioning her to make work.

title: A Love Story Heating Up: Justin Bieber + Maple Leafs
description: TORONTO  This is a story about two Canadian things with a well-documented history of ups and downs, and their white-hot bromance.

title: What Our Editors Are Having for Dinner
description: I always love hearing what my New York Times Food co-workers are cooking at home. Not only do their endorsements carry a lot of weight with me, but there is something delightfully illuminating in finding out what people have for dinner. It makes me feel I know them that much better.

title: In Favor of a More Casual, More Forgiving Polenta
description: LONDON  We are all in this together has been said a lot in the past year.

title: For Some Women, Working for Cuomo Is the Worst Place to Be
description: In the office of Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, there are usually two annual holiday parties: one, near the New York State Capitol, for all executive employees, and another, at the Governors Mansion.

title: British Cycling Doctor Ordered Drug in Doping Case, Panel Finds
description: The former doctor for some of Britains most successful cyclists and teams was found guilty on Friday of ordering a banned drug that he knew would be used to enhance a riders performance.

title: Vasectomy Mayhem Trademark Draws Complaint From N.C.A.A.
description: The N.C.A.A. has filed a complaint against a urology practice in Virginia that trademarked the phrase Vasectomy Mayhem, which the athletic association said was confusingly similar to March Madness, its basketball tournament brand.

title: Goodwill Zwelithini ka Bhekuzulu, King of the Zulu Nation, Dies at 72
description: JOHANNESBURG  Goodwill Zwelithini ka Bhekuzulu, the king of South Africas Zulu nation, who shepherded his people from the apartheid era into a modern democratic society, died on Friday in the eastern coastal city of Durban. He was 72.

title: Cancel Americas Student Loan Debt! But How?
description: Imagine if we wiped away every Americans student loan debt? Should we? Thats the topic of today's episode with Jane Coaston.

title: In the last year, older adults tended to be more positive than younger ones, surveys show.
description: For all its challenges to mental health, the past year also put psychological science to the test, and in particular one of its most consoling truths: that age and emotional well-being tend to increase together, as a rule, even as mental acuity and physical health taper off.

title: Our Virtual Pandemic Year
description: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.

title: Beyond Trend: An Honest Conversation About Fashion, Race, Elitism and Community
description: It was just over a year ago, during the fall 2020 show season, that the fashion world gathered together in one place for the last time. Since then, the twin forces of the pandemic and the social justice movement have riven the industry, forcing it to take a new look at an old system and confront questions that had been papered over for years  especially its own history of racism.

title: Myanmars Defiant Garment Workers Demand That Fashion Pay Attention
description: Ma Moe Sandar Myint is the leader of one of Myanmars largest garment worker unions. Until recently, the 37-year-old mother of three and former sewing machine operator would spend her days representing workers with labor complaints and helping members of the Federation of Garment Workers Myanmar unionize their factories.

title: His Ancestors Were German Kings. He Wants Their Treasures Back.
description: POTSDAM, Germany  Georg Friedrich Prinz von Preussens quest to recover thousands of artworks and artifacts that were once in his familys possession is not going well.

title: Awkward Encounters With Sally Rooneys Intense, Lovelorn Characters
Listen to Five of the Worlds Newest, Wildest Instruments
description: What possesses someone to invent a new instrument? Ask the finalists of this years Guthman Musical Instrument Competition, and you get different answers  among them boredom, curiosity, frustration.

title: Jaime Herrera Beutler Is Undaunted
description: It was well past bedtime when Representative Jaime Herrera Beutler caused a stir during the first impeachment of President Donald J. Trump by bringing her 6-year-old daughter to the House floor to witness history and watch her mother vote no.

title: The Mysterious Link Between COVID-19 and Sleep
description: The coronavirus can cause insomnia and long-term changes in our nervous systems. But sleep could also be a key to ending the pandemic.

title: George Floyds Family Settles Suit Against Minneapolis for $27 Million
description: [Watch Live: Derek Chauvin on trial for George Floyds Death]

title: A survey of Republicans shows 5 factions have emerged after Trumps presidency.
description: The Republican Party in the era following Donald J. Trumps presidency is comprised of five tribes that have ranging affinity for the former president and different desires when it comes to seeing him continue to lead the party, according to a new survey by Mr. Trumps former pollster.

title: School Wasnt So Great Before COVID, Either
description: Yes, remote schooling has been a misery  but its offering a rare chance to rethink early education entirely.

title: Desert X Artists Dig Beneath the Sandy Surface
description: PALM SPRINGS, Calif.  The odds were fully stacked against the Desert X biennial taking place this year. Bigger and better-organized destination exhibitions have punted on their plans since the pandemic struck, and even in the best of years, Desert X, which commissions site-specific public art in and around Palm Springs, has a hard time raising money to realize its projects. Its decision two years ago to accept funding from the Saudi Arabian government for a spinoff event caused prominent board members to resign and artists to speak out in protest.

title: You Cant Bathe. You Cant Wash. Water Crisis Hobbles Jackson, Miss., for Weeks
description: JACKSON, Miss.  Once again, Lavern Avant was spending her day scouring Mississippis capital city, hoping to get her hands on a basic necessity that she and many of her neighbors had gone without for weeks.

title: Love Letter: Reclaiming Her Power With Celibacy
description: Childhood trauma can often leave a lasting imprint. Paula McLain, the writer of this weeks Modern Love essay, took a vow of celibacy after a string of failed relationships left her emotionally depleted. For her, abstaining from sex meant finally healing from the past and learning to love and accept herself.

title: Thulani Davis and the Secret History of Women Writing Album Liner Notes
description: If its Grammy season, its time for the annual attention paid to what many see as the Recording Academys longstanding and well-known diversity challenges, its preponderance for awarding Black artists in niche rather than mainstream categories, and its poor track record acknowledging the contributions of women across the board.

title: As more of the U.S. returns to indoor dining, restaurant workers clamor for vaccine access.
description: More and more of the United States has relaxed restrictions on indoor dining, but the number of states allowing workers in the restaurant industry to get a Covid-19 vaccine has been slow to rise.

title: Michigan broadens vaccine access to include everyone 16 and older as of April 5.
description: Michigan will expand vaccine eligibility to everyone 50 and older as of March 22, and to everyone 16 and older as of April 5, Gov. Gretchen Whitmer said on Friday. The announcement came a day after President Bidens prime-time address, in which he directed states to expand eligibility to all adults by May 1.

title: The Daily: The Children in Government Detention
description: Hi, everyone, and welcome to Friday. Our team is grateful to be inching toward spring and ready to say goodbye forever to this pandemic winter (at least in the Northern Hemisphere). We hope its sunny wherever you are.

title: Countries Tried to Curb Trade in Plastic Waste. The U.S. Is Shipping More.
description: When more than 180 nations agreed last year to place strict limits on exports of plastic waste from richer countries to poorer ones, the move was seen as a major victory in the fight against plastic pollution.

title: Back to School: N.C.A.A. Tournament Bracket Wont Be Built as Usual
description: Perhaps you played college basketball or just fancy yourself an expert bracketologist because you won your pool back when Kentucky actually made the national tournament. Maybe youve spent this March obsessing over one-bid conferences you wont remember until next March. Losing $20 might be as much a personal rite around this time of year as allergies in Atlanta or the green-dyed Chicago River.

title: Why the Rape Claim Against Australias Attorney General Seems Familiar
description: He was accused of sexual assault decades after it allegedly occurred, in a way that makes police investigation all but impossible. Backed by his party and the most powerful man in the country, he maintained his innocence and held one of the most important legal positions in the country, even as questions continued to swirl around him.

title: The Science Behind Your Need for One More Potato Chip
description: HOOKEDFood, Free Will, and How the Food Giants Exploit Our AddictionsBy Michael Moss

title: Ode to Naps
description: Go ahead, take one.

title: Imbolo Mbue on Writing Her Second Novel
description: Imbolo Mbue first began writing her new novel, How Beautiful We Were, in 2002. The book concerns the impact of an American oil companys presence on a fictional African village. She eventually put the idea aside to work on what turned into her acclaimed debut novel, Behold the Dreamers. When she began working again on the earlier idea, it was 2016. On this weeks podcast, she says that returning to the novel at that moment changed the way she approached writing it.

title: Learning to Love Daylight Saving Time
description: Americans in every state except Arizona and Hawaii will lose an hour of sleep this weekend as the nation ushers in daylight saving time, and you may join me in wondering why were torturing ourselves. Why do we use one time-keeping system for 34 weeks and a different system the other 18? Why not pick one and stick with it?

title: The Fighter Jet Thats Too Pricey to Fail
description: Last week, the new head of the House Armed Services Committee, Representative Adam Smith, said in an interview that the F-35 fighter jet was a rathole draining money. He said the Pentagon should consider whether to cut its losses. That promptly set off another round of groaning about the most expensive weapon system ever built, and questions about whether it should  or could  be scrapped.

title: The Calls for Andrew Cuomo to Resign
description: To the Editor:

title: Paul Jones, a Hamptonite of Many Pursuits, Dies at 40
description: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

title: The Weekender
description: Who bakes the best bagels? A Times critic weighs in. Also in this edition: The gardening show that became indispensable viewing, the plan to protect Indigenous elders living under the Northern Lights, and more.

title: The W.H.O. grants emergency authorization to the Johnson & Johnson vaccine, a boost for global vaccination efforts.
description: The World Health Organization granted emergency authorization on Friday to Johnson & Johnsons Covid-19 vaccine, adding the first one-dose option to the W.H.O.s global arsenal against the pandemic.

title: What to Do This Weekend
description: Want to get the At Home newsletter in your inbox? Sign up here.

title: Why Al Franken Hovers Over the Debate About Cuomos Future
description: Stephanie Miner is no friend of Andrew Cuomo.

title: A Green Wave? Mexicos Marijuana Market May Be Middling
description: MEXICO CITY  Mexico, a country carved up by cartels for decades, is poised to take a major step in drug policy. This week, the lower house of Congress approved a landmark bill to legalize recreational marijuana, which would make it the worlds largest legal market for the drug.

title: Beeple Has Won. Heres What Weve Lost.
description: I want to be a machine, Andy Warhol once said. Apparently the public wouldnt mind either.

title: The Best of Late Night This Week
description: Oprah Winfrey's interview with Meghan Markle and Prince Harry was a big topic for the late-night hosts this week. Here's what they had to say.

title: 5 Fresh Seder Dishes Youll Want to Make All the Time
description: Another trip around the sun during Covid means another year of Zoom Seders. Whether virtual or in-person, a good Seder service can take a few hours with only ceremonial nibbles like matzo, haroseth, parsley and  get excited  a hard-boiled egg dipped in salt water. Hunger builds, but at least theres wine.

title: Biden Celebrates the Passing of Covid-19 Relief Bill
description: During an event in the Rose Garden on Friday, President Biden celebrated the passing of the $1.9 trillion coronavirus relief bill that will help revive the economy stunned by the pandemic.

title: I Want to Buy Vintage and Used Clothes Online. But How?
description: Welcome to the age of re-commerce. Its one of my favorite new terms.

title: Too Much on the Bottom and Not Enough in the Middle: Nanaimo Bar Outrage
description: This week was the first anniversary of the official declaration that the coronavirus was a global pandemic. But a number of Canada Letter readers have recently emailed about a very different issue: the correct layer proportions of Nanaimo bars.

title: How the Pandemic Changed the Way We Read
description: People turned to books for comfort, distraction and escape. Here's what the numbers show.

title: The pace of U.S. vaccinations has been accelerating ahead of the date by which Biden wants all adults to be eligible.
description: President Bidens call for every adult American to be eligible for a coronavirus vaccine by May 1 comes at a time when doses are being administered at an accelerated pace.

title: Leon Gast, Director of When We Were Kings, Dies at 84
description: Leon Gast, a filmmaker whose 22-year quest to make When We Were Kings, a documentary about Muhammad Ali and George Foremans epic 1974 boxing match, involved a Liberian shell company, the Hells Angels, a drug deal gone bad, the singer Wyclef Jean and ultimately an Academy Award, died on Monday at his home in Woodstock, N.Y. He was 84.

title: 5 Pies Perfect for Pi Day
description: They say the only constant in life is change, but consider two others: the ratio of a circles circumference to its diameter, better known as pi, and the love the NYT Cooking team has for pie.

title: Biden Takes First Tentative Steps to Address Global Vaccine Shortage
description: WASHINGTON  President Biden, under intense pressure to donate excess coronavirus vaccines to needy nations, moved on Friday to address the global shortage in another way, partnering with Japan, India and Australia to expand global vaccine manufacturing capacity.

title: Well Be Back, Broadway Says, on Shutdown Anniversary
description: One year ago, the grim news that Broadway was shutting down was sweeping through the theater district. Performers were packing up their things and heading home; theater staff were stationed in lobbies to intercept ticket holders and explain to them that the show was canceled.

title: Meet the Best New Artist Grammy Nominees
description: Best new artist is one of the big four Grammy categories: an all-genre contest with plenty of buzz and controversy. Who will win this year?

title: Stimulus Payments to Start Arriving This Weekend
description: The Treasury Department said on Friday that stimulus payments would begin arriving in bank accounts by direct deposit this weekend as the Biden administration tries to get much-needed money to struggling families.

title: The $69 Million Beeple NFT Was Bought With Cryptocurrency
description: An artwork by Beeple which exists only as a digital file and was sold as a nonfungible token for a staggering $69.3 million at an online auction handled by Christies on Thursday was bought by an investor known only by a pseudonym and who paid for it with cryptocurrency, the auction house said Friday.

title: Bidens Goals Are Clear. Now He Has to Achieve Them.
description: WASHINGTON  Having used a national television address Thursday night to offer Americans a bit of hope  including the tantalizing prospect of a Fourth of July with friends and family  President Biden now faces daunting challenges that will determine whether he succeeds in making good on that promise.

title: What to Know About Kathy Hochul, Cuomos Possible Successor
description: BUFFALO  As Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo confronts the greatest political crisis of his career, amid multiple accusations of sexual harassment and growing demands for his resignation, New Yorkers are growing more curious about Lt. Gov. Kathy Hochul, who would replace him if he were no longer in office.

title: A Last-Minute Add to Stimulus Bill Could Restrict State Tax Cuts
description: WASHINGTON  A last-minute change in the $1.9 trillion economic relief package that President Biden signed into law this week includes a provision that could temporarily prevent states that receive government aid from turning around and cutting taxes.

title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
description: So much of this newsletter can be doom and gloom, but today were going to talk about a sunnier outlook. This week I heard that my colleague Ezra Klein, an Opinion columnist, was working on a podcast episode about the near future of the pandemic that was highly optimistic. That was surprising news, given that just a few weeks ago Ezra penned a rather bleak column about the virus.

title: Andrew Cuomo, Global Vaccines, Daylight Saving: Your Friday Evening Briefing
description: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Heres the sign-up.)

title: Former Bolivian Leader Is Arrested for Ouster of Morales
description: Bolivias former interim president, Jeanine Aez, said Friday that she and several allies face arrest following the issuance of a warrant accusing her of terrorism and sedition in connection with the 2019 ouster of her predecessor, former president Evo Morales.

title: As Cleveland Searches for a Name, a Fan Roots for His Trademark
description: After decades of resisting calls to change their name, the Cleveland Indians announced last July that they would discuss the future of their moniker in the wake of intensified calls for social reform throughout the country. Five months later, the team went a step further, saying it would drop the name it has used since 1915, beginning as soon as the 2022 season.

title: How Democrats Hope to Press Their Advantage on the Stimulus
description: President Biden signed his $1.9 trillion coronavirus relief bill into law yesterday, a move that will send $1,400 stimulus checks to many Americans, strengthen a wide range of social programs and step up investment in vaccine distribution. A few hours later, he went on national television to trumpet the achievement. And this afternoon, he celebrated it in a Rose Garden ceremony, joined by Democratic leaders in Congress.

title: After Capitol Riot, Lawmakers Chafe at Security Measures
description: WASHINGTON  Lawmakers in both parties are increasingly agitating to scale back the security measures put in place around the Capitol in the aftermath of the Jan. 6 riot, intensifying a debate over how to balance safety concerns and public access to a building that is a symbol of democracy.

title: Coyote That Attacked Five in Bay Area Is Finally Caught
description: The Bay Areas long, furry nightmare is finally over.

title: Microsoft Executive Says Tech Consolidation Threatens Journalism
description: Brad Smith, Microsofts president, told Congress he supports the Journalism Competition and Protection Act, which empowers news publishers to collectively bargain with online platforms like Facebook and Google.

title: Refugee Flights Canceled as Biden Fails to Lift Trump Cutback
description: More than 715 refugees from around the world who expected to start new lives in the United States have had their flights canceled in recent weeks because President Biden has postponed an overhaul of his predecessors sharp limits on new refugee admissions.

title: Bryson DeChambeau Keeps the Crowd Riveted at the Players Championship
description: PONTE VEDRA BEACH, Fla.  Throughout the second round of the Players Championship on Friday, an entertaining crew of the worlds best golfers vied for the tournament lead. But for several hours, most fans were transfixed by a different matter: Whether Bryson DeChambeau would hit a prudent iron or take a mighty lash with his driver on hole after hole.

title: George Floyds Family Settles Suit for $27 Million
description: Minneapolis agreed on Friday to pay $27 million to the family of George Floyd, the Black man whose killing by a white police officer was caught on video and ignited months of nationwide protests.

title: Statement of Inevitability
description: SATURDAY PUZZLE  We have a nice multigrain loaf of a themeless today, filling, with lots of diverse nuts and seeds throughout. John Guzzetta is an all-purpose constructor, but the bulk of his efforts come on Fridays and Saturdays; this feels like a Saturday to me in scope, but solves pretty smoothly.

title: Quotation of the Day: U.S. Takes Step to Use Vaccine for Diplomacy
description: Its time for U.S. leaders to ask themselves: When this pandemic is over, do we want the world to remember Americas leadership helping distribute lifesaving vaccines, or will we leave that to others?

title: Ebola Survivor Infected Years Ago May Have Started New Outbreak
description: An Ebola outbreak now occurring in Guinea was almost certainly started by someone who survived West Africas historic 2014-16 epidemic, harbored the virus for at least five years and then transmitted it via semen to a sex partner, researchers reported on Friday.

title: Corrections: March 13, 2021
description: An article on Thursday about the passage of the stimulus bill by Congress misattributed the quotation The American people are going to see an American comeback this year, but it wont be because of this liberal bill. It was from Representative Kevin McCarthy of California, not Senator Mitch McConnell of Kentucky.

title: Sorry About Your Sleep
description: Hello. You may be here to learn when is daylight saving time, or what is the time that were saving, or why does daylight saving time even exist.

title: A $27 million settlement for George Floyds family could influence jurors.
description: The City of Minneapolis agreed on Friday to pay $27 million to the family of George Floyd, the Black man whose death set off months of protests after a video showed a white police officer kneeling on his neck.

title: China asks visa applicants to get inoculated with Chinese-made vaccines.
description: BEIJING  China raised the stakes in the international vaccine competition on Saturday, saying that foreigners wishing to enter the Chinese mainland from Hong Kong will face fewer paperwork requirements if they are inoculated with Chinese-made coronavirus vaccines.

title: Despite Encouraging Downward Trend, U.S. Covid Deaths Remain High
description: Nearly 1,500 people are still dying of Covid-19 every day in the United States, a number that is lower than peaks seen last spring and early this year but exceeds the highest rate in July.

title: Will Republicans Pay a Price for Opposing the Stimulus?
description: Hi. Welcome to On Politics, your wrap-up of the week in national politics. Im Lisa Lerer, your host. Sign up here to get On Politics in your inbox every weekday.

title: Over 3 Million People Took This Course on Happiness. Heres What Some Learned.
description: The Yale happiness class, formally known as Psyc 157: Psychology and the Good Life, is one of the most popular classes to be offered in the universitys 320-year history.

title: Tony Hawk and Family Hit the Open Road During Quarantine
description: In early July, Tony Hawk and Catherine Goodman, rounded up their six children, Riley Hawk, 28, Spencer Hawk, 21, Miles Goodman, 21, Keegan Hawk, 19, Calvin Goodman, 18, and Kadence Hawk, 12, for a road trip across the western United States in an R.V.

title: A Drunken Hazing, a Fatal Fall and a Cornell Fraternitys Silence
description: Flavia Tomasello was overwhelmed by the smell of alcohol as she made her way into the Cornell University fraternity house where her missing son had last been seen. It was parents weekend, and she was supposed to have met him at the campus bookstore that morning, but he never showed up. By 10 p.m., he still wasnt answering his phone. His friends hadnt seen him all day.

title: Schumer and a Teachers Union Leader Secure Billions for Private Schools
description: WASHINGTON  Tucked into the $1.9 trillion pandemic rescue law is something of a surprise coming from a Democratic Congress and a president long seen as a champion of public education  nearly $3 billion earmarked for private schools.

title: Kate Baer Is Speaking Truth. From Her Minivan.
description: Before the pandemic, when she could afford a babysitter, Kate Baer would write from a Panera Bread near her home in Hummelstown, Pa., where her favorite staffer, Annemarie, would save her the booth with the power outlet and didnt mind if she brought her own food.

title: A Times Writer on Missing  The Times
description: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.

title: 17 Reasons to Let the Economic Optimism Begin
description: The 21st-century economy has been a two-decade series of punches in the gut.

title: Covid? What Covid? Taiwan Thrives as a Bubble of Normality.
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan  As the coronavirus has upended lives and economies around the world, Taiwan has been an oasis.

title: Protecting Lions Helps the Whole Food Chain? Actually, We Dont Know.
description: Tourists visit South Africas wildlife reserves to see lions and leopards, not civets and servals.

title: The 21 Club Isnt Dead. Yet.
description: It should not have, but it came as a shock that the jockeys had vanished. There theyd stood outside the 21 Club on West 52nd Street for decades, 35 of them, with their cast metal arms upraised to grasp the reins of some invisible mount, their silks brightly painted in the colors of storied thoroughbred stables. Suddenly, then, they were gone.

title: From Crypto Art to Trading Cards, Investment Manias Abound
description: To hear more audio stories from publishers like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

title: Maggots, Rape and Yet Five Stars: How U.S. Ratings of Nursing Homes Mislead the Public
description: Twelve years ago, the U.S. government introduced a powerful new tool to help people make a wrenching decision: which nursing home to choose for loved ones at their most vulnerable. Using a simple star rating  one being the worst, five the best  the system promised to distill reams of information and transform an emotional process into one based on objective, government-blessed metrics.

title: A Political Hurricane Blew Through Georgia. Now Its Bracing for More.
description: ATLANTA  The death threats finally appeared to be subsiding, Brad Raffensperger was happy to report.

title: Despite Covid Outbreaks, Youth Sports Played On
description: NEW ORLEANS  As a coach in a sport where social distancing is impossible, Andrew Nicola said he did all he could to keep the students on his wrestling team safe during the pandemic  following rules on restricting spectators, disinfecting mats between rounds and requiring wrestlers to change into clean singlets between every match.

title: One Year Together, Apart
description: In the year since the pandemic began, people learned to be together while apart and navigated the pain of feeling apart while together. Screens, small and large, became crucial links to the rest of the world.

title: Can Frances Far Right Rise to Power? One Mayor Shows How.
description: PERPIGNAN, France  Riding high in the polls ahead of the next presidential election, feeling theyve won the battle over ideas, smelling blood in the lyse Palace, leaders of Frances far right cocked their eyes across the land at perhaps the one thing standing between them and power: beavers.

title: The Other Kushners Next Move
description: The DealBook newsletter delves into a single topic or theme every weekend, providing reporting and analysis that offers a better understanding of an important issue in the news. If you dont already receive the daily newsletter, sign up here.

title: Can the World Learn From South Africas Vaccine Trials?
description: In a year that has seesawed between astonishing gains and brutal setbacks on Covid-19, few moments were as sobering as the revelation last month that a coronavirus variant in South Africa was dampening the effect of one of the worlds most potent vaccines.

title: Global vaccination rates are on the rise, but many countries have yet to start.
description: More than 345 million doses of Covid-19 vaccines have been administered worldwide in the three months since mass inoculation began in December, but there is still a huge disparity in the vaccination rates between countries.

title: How a Longstanding Rivalry Spiraled Into 5 Deaths Between 2 Families
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Bismillah Adel Aymaq, a prominent radio journalist in western Afghanistan, was preparing a groundbreaking report late last year that accused a provincial council member of corruption.

title: Concerns over the AstraZeneca vaccine. Older people are happier. The week in Covid-19 news.
description: A handful of countries in Europe are shying away from the vaccine developed by AstraZeneca and the University of Oxford. Demark, Norway and Iceland said Thursday they would halt its use while European drug regulators examine the possibility of a link to blood-clotting issues. They emphasized that they were just being cautious and that there is no evidence of any causal link, and global health authorities confirmed support for the vaccine.

title: Banned Vigil for Sarah Everard Becomes Large Anti-Violence Rally Instead
description: LONDON  Thousands of people gathered in south London on Saturday for a vigil in tribute to Sarah Everard, the 33-year-old marketing executive whose killing has touched off a national reckoning over violence against women, despite police warnings that the event would be unlawful.

title: After a 28-Year Ban, Alabama Could Allow Yoga in Public Schools
description: For nearly three decades, teaching yoga in Alabamas public schools has been forbidden by the states school board.

title: Can You Have a Puppy and Nice Furniture?
description: Q: My partner and I are in a four-legged standoff. He wants a puppy because, Puppies! I dont because we just decorated our wonderful Cobble Hill apartment. I can already see a puppy turning the wood legs of our coffee table into his favorite chew toy. And what about our poor sisal rug? My partner insists that people with dogs have nice furniture, and ours will survive if we train our puppy. Im not so sure. Whos right?

title: Spring Is Coming
description: Were setting the clocks forward tonight, a sign that spring is (finally) around the corner. Another sign? NYT Cooking readers are saving asparagus recipes to their recipe boxes: Melissa Clarks asparagus, goat cheese and tarragon tart (above) and Ali Slagles turmeric-black pepper chicken with asparagus were among our most popular recipes this week. Readers also loved Millie Peartrees sheet-pan roasted mushrooms and spinach and Ali Slagles creamy braised white beans. Make any one of them, and get excited for the new season.

title: A Vaccine Makers Investment: Emergent BioSolutions Responds
description: To the Editor:

title: Taiwan, a Covid-19 outlier, is selling something scarce: life without fear of the virus.
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan  As the coronavirus has upended lives and economies around the world, Taiwan has been an oasis.

title: TikTok and the Pop Music Rough Draft
description: Most of the biggest pop music success stories of the last year  loosely the quarantine era in the United States  owe at least some of their success to TikTok, the social video app thats become the most seamless and effective promotional mechanism in the music business.

title: Two Decades After the End of Welfare, Democrats Are Changing Direction
description: WASHINGTON  A quarter-century ago, a Democratic president celebrated the end of welfare as we know it, challenging the poor to exercise independence and espousing balanced budgets and smaller government.

title: In U.S. nursing homes, where Covid-19 killed scores, even reports of maggots and rape dont dock five-star ratings.
description: Twelve years ago, the U.S. government introduced a powerful new tool to help people make a wrenching decision: which nursing home to choose for loved ones at their most vulnerable. Using a simple star rating  one being the worst, five the best  the system promised to distill reams of information and transform an emotional process into one based on objective, government-blessed metrics.

title: Variety: Acrostic
description: ACROSTIC  If youre here for hints, get ready to spring forward and finish this acrostic. That last sentence is kind of a spoiler, actually, especially if it reminds you (as it did me) that daylight saving happens this weekend; thats the subject of the passage today. Its from a book called Spring Forward: The Annual Madness of Daylight Saving Time, by Michael Downing, and it involves a proposal by an American founding father that long preceded electric light.

title: After Breonna Taylors Death, Black Engagement in Kentucky Politics Soared
description: Exactly one year ago, a young woman died as a barrage of police gunfire ripped through the walls of her modest apartment in Louisville, Ky. For months, her death went largely unrecognized.

title: Id Much Rather Be in Florida
description: To hear more audio stories from publishers like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

title: Whistle-Blower Says Credit Suisse Helped Clients Skip Taxes After Promising to Stop
description: Seven years after Credit Suisse promised federal prosecutors that it would stop helping rich Americans hide their wealth from tax collectors, a whistle-blower is contending that it continued to do just that, raising the possibility that the Swiss bank could face a fresh investigation and steep financial penalties.

title: Patrick Dupond, French Ballet Virtuoso, Dies at 61
description: Patrick Dupond, a star dancer and former director of the Paris Opera Ballet who won worldwide renown in the 1980s and 90s for his virtuosity, glittering technique and flamboyant personality, died on March 5 in Soissons, France. He was 61.

title: Stimulus Bill Transforms Options For State and Local Governments
description: Richard F. Cortez, the top elected official in Hidalgo County, at the southern tip of Texas, is so full of anticipation for the federal stimulus money that is about to flow into his county that he has memorized the precise amount and happily recites it: $212,702,647.

title: Behind the Reporting of the Talibans Secret Prisons
description: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.

title: On a Storied Stretch of Fifth Avenue, a Symbol of Irish America Reels
description: An exquisite Fifth Avenue townhouse of Gilded Age pedigree is on the market for $52 million. It features five stories, a curved terrace and a history that reads like a tragedy of manners, filled with grandeur and pride, pettiness and decay.

title: Luis Palau, the Billy Graham of Latin America, Dies at 86
description: Luis Palau, who rose from preaching on street corners in Argentina to become one of the most significant evangelical leaders in the generation following his mentor, Billy Graham, died on Thursday at his home in Portland, Ore. He was 86.

title: Born in Soviet Exile, They Might Die in a Russian One
description: NIZHNY ODES, Russia  Long lines of people waiting to buy milk, toilet paper and other essentials disappeared from Russia decades ago. But one line has only grown longer  the one Yevgeniya B. Shasheva has been waiting in.

title: Announcer Caught on Open Mic Using Racial Slur at Basketball Game
description: A sports announcer at an Oklahoma high school basketball game uttered a racial slur into a live microphone as players on the court knelt during the national anthem on Thursday night, prompting widespread outrage and condemnation.

title: Hundreds of Tesla workers tested positive for the virus after Elon Musk reopened a plant, data shows.
description: More than 400 workers at a Tesla plant in California tested positive for the coronavirus between May and December, according to public health data released by a transparency website.

title: Protesters Defy Covid Restrictions to Rally for Slain London Woman
description: Thousands of people gathered at Clapham Common on Saturday, the London park near where Sarah Everard, 33, was last seen alive. Her death led to an outpouring of anger and solidarity over violence against women.

title: The Imperious Rise and Accelerating Fall of Andrew Cuomo
description: Last spring, when the coronavirus outbreak was surging in New York, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomos daily briefings became appointment television for many, as he authoritatively ticked through the latest statistics on infections, hospital beds and deaths.

title: At Kosovo Monastery, Nationalist Clamor Disturbs the Peace
description: DECAN, Kosovo  Inside the walls of Father Sava Janjics 14th-century monastery reign silence and calm, interrupted by the occasional soft footfall of the few monks remaining in this revered outpost of the Serbian Orthodox Church in a hostile western Kosovo.

title: Let's Stress-Eat Some Chips Together
description: Sam Anderson says this snack will rescue us from the very worst things on our screens. Listen to him make his case and sail off into the salty seas of decadent gluttony, guilt-free.

title: More travelers passed through U.S. airports on Friday than any day since March 2020.
description: U.S. airports had 1.357 million people pass through on Friday, the highest number on any day since March 2020, just after the World Health Organization declared the coronavirus outbreak a pandemic.

title: Chris Harrison Replaced as Bachelorette Host by 2 Former Contestants
description: Chris Harrison will not host the next season of The Bachelorette for the first time in the history of the franchise, which began as a guilty pleasure when it debuted in 2002 but has in recent years been criticized for its lack of diversity and insensitive handling of race.

title: Three Uber passengers coughed on a driver and ripped off his mask. Two have been arrested.
description: Two arrests have been made after scenes from a viral video that circulated showed passengers taunting and deliberately coughing on an Uber driver.

title: They All Laughed
description: SUNDAY PUZZLE  Who all laughed? Maybe you all laughed, working on this quirky grid that features a venerable humor magazine and one of its most famous contributors. Were looking at a real labor of love by Jacob Stulberg, a second-year law student at New York University, a 13-year veteran of the Times puzzle and a superfan of the magazine in question. How super? Check your back copies: If you have the December 1995 issue (No. 341), theres a letter to the editor from our constructor, correcting the editorial misuse of the term gluteus maximus.

title: At least 7 Covid-19 patients die in Jordan because of an oxygen shortage, a growing problem around the world.
description: At least seven people died at a hospital in Jordan on Saturday after it ran out of oxygen, according to Jordanian news reports, prompting an outcry in the kingdom, a visit to the hospital by King Abdullah II and the resignations of the countrys health minister and the hospitals director.

title: Can Andrew Cuomo Continue to Lead?
description: Few political families have had more of an impact on New York politics than the Cuomos. Father and firstborn son both had public service woven deep in their DNA, and both developed a reputation for toughness in service of the common good and their own political ambitions.

title: Hundreds March in Louisville a Year After Breonna Taylors Death
description: On the anniversary of her death, the family of Breonna Taylor rallied in Louisville, Ky., on Saturday alongside supporters and the families of several other people of color who were fatally shot by police around the country.

title: Grammys 2021: How to Watch, Time and Streaming
description: Its pandemic awards-show season, which, thus far, has meant a lot of technological glitches and acceptance speeches given from the couch. But the executive producer of the Grammys on Sunday promises that this one wont give you Zoom fatigue.

title: Rick Pitino Forges a New Path to the Tournament With Iona
description: ATLANTIC CITY, N.J.  The old Atlantic City Boardwalk Hall, with its Renaissance-style architecture, its grand arched roof and the worlds largest pipe organ, is a fitting platform for a final act. And so, there was Rick Pitino late Saturday afternoon, with only family members and friends in the cavernous arena, stalking the sidelines in a dapper navy suit, waving his rolled-up notes around like a maestro conducting an orchestra.

title: Go Fly a (Newspaper) Kite!
description: Easy to build, simple to fly, the diamond kite  two sticks crossed and bound together, covered by a diamond-shaped piece of paper  is the most recognized kite shape in the Western world. A woodcut image from the 1600s is the oldest known reference to the diamond kite. And all it requires is a couple of sticks, some newspaper and string.

title: Quotation of the Day: 10 Years Ago, the Village Was Erased
description: Our ancestors lived in this village 1,000 years ago. There were disasters then, too. Each time the people stayed. They rebuilt and stayed. Rebuilt and stayed. I feel an obligation to continue what my ancestors started. I dont want to lose my hometown.

title: Marvelous Marvin Hagler, Middleweight Champion of the 1980s, Dies at 66
description: Marvelous Marvin Hagler, who became one of boxings greatest middleweight champions, wielding awesome punching power while shrugging off opponents blows, died on Saturday in New Hampshire. He was 66 and lived in Bartlett, N.H.

title: You Probably Need New Running Shoes. Heres How to Upgrade.
description: If you run, youre a runner. And if youre a runner, especially one who has hit the pavement more in the past year, theres a good chance you need to upgrade your running shoes.

title: How the Pandemic Has Transformed the Idea of Home
description: Before the pandemic began, your home may have merely been a place to sleep. Or maybe it was a precious escape from the hustle and bustle of the outside world. But now, a year after the World Health Organization declared the coronavirus outbreak a pandemic, home has taken on an entirely new meaning. A year of lockdowns and various restrictions have forced millions of people around the world to adapt to their spaces and exist within the confines of four walls. Many could no longer afford to pay rent and subsequently lost their homes, their sense of security.

title: Enjoy a Book Tour, In Your Living Room
description: Authors releasing books in the past year have experienced a radically altered literary landscape  perhaps most significantly, they have lost the ability to venture out on the standard book tour, which typically includes a series of readings and talks across the country. While many book lovers yearn for the days of big-name events or cozy chats at indie bookstores, others are enjoying access for the first time. For those who do not live in the major cities and college towns that tend to be destinations for top writers, the pandemic has offered them the ability to experience these events online.

title: Cook Persian Food and Practice Meditation
description: Here is a sampling of the weeks events and how to tune in (all times are Eastern). Note that events are subject to change after publication.

title: N.C.A.A. Tournament: Things to Know Going Into Selection Sunday
description: One year after the pandemic-induced cancellation of the N.C.A.A. mens basketball tournament resulted in a $600 million decline in the N.C.A.A.s revenue for 2020, March Madness is back in 2021.

title: Womens Basketball Makes Room for New Stars, and New Contenders
description: There are few more compelling diversions than N.C.A.A. tournament basketball, and after the postseason was canceled last March because of the coronavirus pandemic, plenty of the best players in womens basketball are hungry for the bright lights of the big stage. Their passion for the game will, at least for the next few weeks, become our own as we become immersed in the brackets glories and heartbreaks.

title: To Reach His Dream, This Teen Will Have to Touch the Sky
description: COPPER MOUNTAIN, Colo.  Like his mother, Brian Rice has played just about every sport.

title: Corrections: March 14, 2020
description: An attribution attached to a quote with an article on Page 10 about New Yorks cultural landscape in the moments before it shut down in March 2020 misspells the given name of an actress. She is Brittney Mack, not Brittsney.

title: When They Have Finished, My Husband Hands Them a 20
description: Dear Diary:

title: Our Autofiction Fixation
description: In February 2020, at a book party in a Brooklyn brownstone, a smiling stranger walked up to me. We have something in common, you know, she said. We conceived our children without having sex. My memory of the exchange then goes blank for a moment  I must have spluttered some confused pleasantry in response  but it quickly emerged that she had read my first novel, which explores its protagonists struggles with infertility, and drawn the conclusion that I myself had undergone I.V.F., as she had.

title: Small Piece of the Stimulus Has Ambitious Aim of Saving Mothers Lives
description: Its easy to overlook amid the hundreds of pages of the $1.9 trillion stimulus plan President Biden signed into law Thursday, but a short section aims to combat Americas maternal mortality crisis by expanding health coverage for new mothers.

title: Livestreaming, Still Niche, Grows as a Tool for Retailers
description: Matt Granite had been working for years as a consumer journalist filming segments that were syndicated on American television stations and sharing additional videos on his YouTube channel, The Deal Guy.

title: Korean TVs Unlikely Star: Subway Sandwiches
description: In an episode of the Korean television show The K2, which takes place in a world of fugitives and bodyguards, a man is being treated with a defibrillator when he enters into a dream state. On the fringe of death, he recalls taking a past love to a Subway restaurant and to a park for a picnic, where he gently feeds her a sandwich and soft drink with the Subway logo facing the camera.

title: The Swag Must Go On: Hollywoods Pandemic Oscar Campaign
description: LOS ANGELES  As a potential Oscar nominee for film editing, William Goldenberg should be feeling dizzy right about now. So many tastemaker cocktail parties to attend. So many panel discussions to participate in.

title: Zack Snyders Rough and Tumble Ride With Justice League
description: Even superhero movies can have dual identities.

title: The Missing Hours: 7 Students on Losing a Year of After-School Activities
description: From 3 p.m. to 6 p.m. That block of time, between the end of classes and the beginning of dinner, were for millions of teenagers everywhere the golden hours of the day. They provided a release from the pressures of school or an escape from a stressful home. It was a time for friendship and fun.

title: Police Shrugged Off the Proud Boys, Until They Attacked the Capitol
description: A protester was burning an American flag outside the 2016 Republican convention in Cleveland when Joseph Biggs rushed to attack. Jumping a police line, he ripped the mans shirt off and started pounding, he boasted that night in an online video.

title: Germany Launches Election Year With Losses for Merkels Party in Two States
description: BERLIN  Voters in two southwestern German states punished Chancellor Angela Merkels conservative party in regional elections on Sunday, early results showed, turning from the Christian Democrats in record numbers amid the coronavirus pandemic and a growing scandal over lawmakers who accepted kickbacks for selling masks.

title: One Year in a Pandemic: Your Weekend Briefing
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: The Week in Business: Here Comes the Stimulus Cash
description: Good morning. Millions of Americans will receive their stimulus payments any minute now, as the American Rescue Plan is up and running. Heres what else you need to know in business and tech news for the week ahead.  Charlotte Cowles

title: Whats Going On in This Picture? | March 15, 2021
U.S. Has 1,000 More Troops in Afghanistan Than It Disclosed
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Facing a high-stakes choice and running out of time to make it, the Biden administration is wrestling with whether to follow through with a full withdrawal in the next seven weeks of the 2,500 American troops still in Afghanistan  except, as it turns out, that number is actually around 3,500.

title: Clergy Preach Faith in the Covid Vaccine to Doubters
description: During a recent Sunday service at the Gathering Place, an evangelical church in Orlando, Fla., the Rev. Gabriel Salguero focused his sermon on the Covid-19 vaccine, and the fear and suspicion that his largely Latino congregation clutches so tightly.

title: Tiny Town, Big Decision: What Are We Willing to Pay to Fight the Rising Sea?
description: AVON, N.C.  Bobby Outten, a county manager in the Outer Banks, delivered two pieces of bad news at a recent public meeting. Avon, a town with a few hundred full-time residents, desperately needed at least $11 million to stop its main road from washing away. And to help pay for it, Dare County wanted to increase Avons property taxes, in some cases by almost 50 percent.

title: The Mixed-Up Brothers of Bogot
description: How two sets of twins, scrambled at birth, had their lives changed in an instant.

title: Days of Killings and Defiance in Myanmar, With Neither Side Relenting
description: Soldiers and police officers shot and killed at least 51 people in Myanmar over the weekend, as they pressed their campaign of attrition against protesters who have defied them in cities and towns across the country.

title: The Sunday Read: The Case for the Subway
description: Long before it became an archaic and filthy symbol of everything wrong with Americas broken cities, the New York subway was a marvel.

title: Homes That Sold for Around $1.5 Million
description: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.

title: Long-Lost Mosaic From a Floating Palace of Caligula Returns Home
description: NEMI, Italy  If stones could speak, the mosaic unveiled recently at an archaeological museum just south of Rome would have quite the tale to tell.

title: A saving grace: Stimulus payments begin to arrive in bank accounts.
description: Stimulus payments have started to land in Americans bank accounts, just days after President Biden signed a $1.9 trillion pandemic rescue bill into law.

title: The last living man of the Juma people in Brazil has died from Covid-19.
description: Aruk Juma saw his Amazon tribe dwindle to just a handful of individuals during his lifetime.

title: Yo-Yo Ma gives a surprise cello concert at a Massachusetts vaccination site.
description: The world-renowned cellist Yo-Yo Ma gave a surprise concert on Saturday at a vaccination site in Massachusetts.

title: Which vaccines are available in the U.S. now, and which may be coming?
description: About 20 percent of the U.S. population has received at least one Covid-19 vaccine shot as the pace of inoculations in the United States sharply climbs. Here is a look at the vaccines that have been authorized by the Food and Drug Administration and where some other vaccine candidates stand.

title: What to Cook This Week
description: Good morning. It is Pi Day, for those who delight in numbers and pay attention to such things: 3.14, a mathematical constant, the ratio of a circles circumference to its diameter. Also a day for untrammeled truth: Everyone loves pie, even those who prefer cake. (And its a day to check your clocks. Time sprang forward an hour last night in accordance with Daylight Saving Time.)

title: Youth sports have seen their share of virus outbreaks, but for many the benefits outweigh the risks.
description: A year after the coronavirus crisis first closed athletic fields and darkened school gyms, students, parents, coaches and officials have struggled to navigate the challenges of youth sports, weighing concerns about transmitting the virus against the social, emotional and sometimes financial benefits of competition.
